metadata.title: Modeling the effects of material properties on the pull-in instability of nonlocal functionally graded nano-actuators

sections.text:
ZAMM · Z. Angew. Math. Mech. 96, No. 3, 385–400 (2016) / DOI 10.1002/zamm.201400160
Modeling the effects of material properties on the pull-in instability of nonlocal functionally graded nano-actuators
Hamid M. Sedighi1,∗, Farhang Daneshmand2,3,4,∗∗, and Mohamadreza Abadyan5,∗∗∗
1 Mechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz, Iran 2 Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, 817 Sherbrooke Street West, Montreal, Quebec, Canada H3A 2K6 3 Department of Bioresource Engineering, McGill University, 21111 Lakeshore Road, Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue, Quebec, Canada H9x3V9 4 School of Mechanical Engineering, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran 5 Shahrekord Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrekord, Iran
Received 17 July 2014, revised 17 December 2014, accepted 20 June 2015 Published online 22 July 2015
Key words Nano-actuator, Casimir attractions, functionally graded material, nonlocal elasticity, dynamic pull-in instability, iteration perturbation method.
Dynamic pull-in behavior of nonlocal functionally graded nano-actuators by considering Casimir attraction is investigated in this paper. It is assumed that the nano-bridge is initially at rest and the fundamental frequency of nano-structure as a function of system parameters is obtained asymptotically by Iteration Perturbation Method (IPM). The effects of actuation voltage, nonlocal parameter, properties of FGM materials and intermolecular force on the dynamic pull-in behavior are studied. It is exhibited that two terms in series expansions are adequate to achieve the acceptable approximations for fundamental frequency as well as the analytic solution. Comparison between the obtained results based on the asymptotic analysis and the reported experimental and numerical results in the literature, verify the effectiveness of the asymptotic analysis.

1 Introduction
Functionally graded materials (FGMs) have found wide applications in engineering sciences. Study and researches about behavior of functionally graded materials (FGMs) have been an interesting topic during the past decades [1, 2]. In recent years, FGMs find increasing applications in micro- and nano- structures, such as thin films in the form of shape memory alloys [3, 4] and micro- or nano-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS) [5–7]. FGMs are special composites whose composition varies continuously as a function of position along thickness of a structure to achieve an appropriate function. This is obtained by gradually varying volume fraction of the constituent materials. FGMs are generally made of a mixture of ceramic and metal to satisfy the demand of ultra-high-temperature environment and to eliminate the interface problems, as ceramic has a low thermal conductivity and thus excellent temperature residence. Accordingly, the area of smart materials and structures has experienced rapid growth. The mechanics of smart structures involve coupling between the mechanical, electrical or thermal effects.
With advances in microfabrication techniques, modelling of FGM microbeams has been considered by theoretical researchers [8]. A non-conventional thin plate theory, coupled with the continuum surface elasticity model has been developed by Lü et al. [2] for nano-scaled FGM films. They studied the effects of length scales, gradient index and aspect ratio on the displacements of FGM nano-plates. Static bending and buckling of a functionally graded (FG) nanobeam was examined by Simsek and Yurtcu [9] based on the nonlocal Timoshenko and Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. Ke and Wang [10] investigated the dynamic stability of microbeams made of functionally graded materials (FGMs) based on the modified couple stress theory and Timoshenko beam theory. They also discussed the influences of the length scale parameter, gradient index and length-to-thickness ratio on the dynamic stability characteristics of FGM microbeams with hinged–hinged and clamped–clamped end supports. Sharafkhani et al. [11] studied the mechanical behavior of a circular functionally graded material (FGM) micro-plate subjected to a nonlinear electrostatic pressure and mechanical shock and investigated the effects of different percentages of metal and ceramic constituent on the response of the system.
∗ Corresponding author email: hmsedighi@gmail.com; h.msedighi@scu.ac.ir∗∗ Email: farhang.daneshmand@mcgill.ca∗∗∗ Email: Abadyan@yahoo.com

386 H. M. Sedighi et al.: Modeling the effects of material properties on the pull-in instability
As the dimensions of a structure approach the nanoscale, new phenomena such as dispersion forces [12, 13] should be taken into consideration. The effect of vacuum fluctuations can be modelled through the dispersion forces, i.e. Casimir attraction and vdW forces. Both Casimir and vdW attractions are connected with the existence of zero-point vacuum oscillations of the electromagnetic field and can be expressed in terms of quantum confinement effects when a pair of parallel plates is brought close together. For close parallel conductive plates, the virtual photon emitted by an atom of one surface reaches an atom of the other surface during its lifetime. The vdW force arises from the correlated oscillations of the instantaneously induced dipole moments of these atoms [14]. However, when the separation between the two surfaces is large enough, the virtual photons emitted by an atom of the first surface cannot reach the second one during its lifetime. In this case, the interaction between two surfaces can be described by Casimir force i.e. retarded vdW attraction. This retardation effect is a result of the finite propagation speed of the electromagnetic field. If the separation between the two surfaces is large enough, i.e. above the plasma wavelength for metallic surfaces or absorption wavelength for dielectric surfaces, the retardation is significant [14, 15]. Thus the quantum fluctuations are modeled in term of Casimir regime for large separations (typically above several ten nanometers) while they are expressed in term of vdW regime for short separations (typically less than several ten nanometers) [16, 17].
Several investigations have been focused on modelling the pull-in instability and nonlinear analysis of nano-scale structures by employing different theories [18–21]. However, the dynamic pull-in instability of FGM nano-actuators based on the nonlocal elasticity theory has not been investigated asymptotically till present. A distributed parameter model was employed by Ramezani et al. [22] to determine the minimum initial gap and detachment length of nano-probes in the presence of dispersion effects and electrostatic actuation. Vibration characteristics of non-uniform single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) conveying fluid embedded in viscoelastic medium has been investigated by Rafiei et al. [23] using nonlocal Euler-Bernoulli beam theory. The influence of surface effects on the pull-in instability of a cantilever nano-actuators has been investigated by Koochi et al. [24] incorporating the influence of Casimir attraction. Pull-in” of a pre-stressed thin film by an electrostatic potential was investigated by Duan and Wan [25]. They extended their model to a two-dimensional (2-D) axisymmetric diaphragm clamped at the periphery and derived the interrelationship between bridge–pad gap, residual membrane stress, critical voltage and pull-in central deflection. The impact of Casimir force on the electromechanical behavior of nanostructures is also demonstrated experimentally by using either bam-type or torsional NEMS [26]. Decca et al. measured the Casimir force between an Au-coated probe and two Au-coated films using torsional system [27]. Chan et al. investigated the Casimir effect in torsional systems consists of a polysilicon rotational mainplate near a spherical metallic surface [28]. Lamoreaux used an electromechanical system based on a torsion pendulum to measure the Casimir force between surfaces at 0.6-6 μm separation distances [29]. Besides, torsional systems, beam-type devices have been employed for investigating the influence of Casimir force in miniature systems. Mohideen utilized an atomic force microscope to make precise detection of the Casimir force between a metallized sphere of diameter 196 μm and flat plate [30]. Munday et al. used an atomic force microscope cantilever for exploring repulsive Casimir force [31]. Bressi et al. have explored the impact of Casimir force between parallel metallic surfaces with 0.5-3.0 μm separation range using cantilever beam-type actuators [32].
In classical continuum mechanics, the influence of small-size is ignored. However, the experimental results have shown that for micro/nanoscale structures, the small-size effects become significant [33,34] and classical elasticity cannot model the size effect contribution in nano-type structures [35, 36]. Mahmoud et al. [20] developed the nonlocal finite element model to study the static bending behavior of nanobeams, taking into consideration the surface effects. A nonlocal finite element model was developed by Eltaher et al. [35] to study the vibration characteristics of nanobeams, taking into account the surface effects. Li et al. [37] presented the analytical solution for the transverse vibration of simply supported nanobeams subjected to an initial axial force based on nonlocal elasticity theory.
Zhao et al. [38] analyzed the nonlinear static bending deformation, the post-bucking problem and the nonlinear free vibration of microbeam model based on strain gradient theory. They demonstrated that the size effect is significant when the ratio of characteristic thickness to internal material length scale parameters is approximately equal to one or two. Kong et al. [39] studied the static and dynamic problems of Bernoulli–Euler beams analytically on the basis of strain gradient elasticity theory.
Study on the asymptotic analysis of nonlinear problems has been rapidly developed in recent years. Several researchers employed the analytical methods such as Max-Min approach, Energy Balance Method, Variational Iteration Method, Homotopy Analysis Method, Homotopy Perturbation Method (HPM) with and auxiliary term, Parameter Expansion Method, Hamiltonian Approach (HA), and Iteration Perturbation Method to study the static and dynamic behaviour of nonlinear systems. Recently, an asymptotic approach namely Iteration Perturbation Method proposed by He [40] has proven to be a very effective and convenient method for solving nonlinear governing equations.
The present article is organized to asymptotically investigate the dynamic pull-in behaviour of nonlocal FGM nanoactuators. The fundamental frequency and analytic solution of vibrating nano-beam in the presence of Casimir intermolecular force is obtained using IPM. To obtain high accurate approximate solutions, two terms in series expansions is taken

into consideration. Finally, the influences of actuation voltage, dispersion force and material and nonlocal parameters on the pull-in instability and fundamental frequency are studied.

Furthermore, the distance of the neutral axis from the top surface is represented by z̃c. The configuration of coordinate system is also indicated in Fig. 2. 3 Approximation by Iteration Perturbation Method

This method is valid not only for weakly nonlinear problems but also for strongly nonlinear differential equations [44,45]. Consider the nonlinear governing equation (25) for the vibration of nonlocal FGM nano-bridge actuated by DC voltage, which is initially at rest and subjected to the following initial conditions
q (0) = 0, q̇ (0) = 0 (26) in order to achieve an iteration perturbation solution of the governing equation, it is convenient to introduce an artificial parameter ε as

4 Results and discussion
4.1 Validation
In order to validate the asymptotic analysis, the values of dynamic pull-in voltage for the system, calculated by different methods, are presented in Table 1. It is obvious from the reported results that the values of dynamic pull-in voltage (Vpid) computed by IPM method agrees well with those computed by Reduced Order model using three modes assumption and

Finite Difference method by Krylov [46]. Furthermore, it is concluded that IPM slightly overestimates the dynamic pull-in voltage in comparison with those obtained by numerical simulations.
Table 2 presents the calculated and measured fundamental frequencies for pre-tensioned micro-bridges. This table reveals that the results of present modelling are in excellent agreement with the numerical and experimental results presented in the literature.

The comparison between the results of numerical and analytical simulations for different values of actuation voltage, have been illustrated in Fig. 3. The first and second orders of approximation using IPM together with the numerical results are depicted in this figure. As clearly shown, the second-order approximate solutions for vibrating nano-beams obtained by IPM display excellent agreement with numerical solutions using Runge-Kutta method.
As another case, the dynamic pull-in voltage of a fixed–fixed silicon beam of length = 1000μm, width = 30μm, height = 2.4μm and initial gap = 10.1μm is modeled. The material properties of the beam is ρ = 2231 kg/m3, E = 97.5 GPa, and υ = 0.26 GPa. The obtained result is presented in Table 3 as well as those reported in literature [50, 51]. The static deformation of this beam has been investigated by Krylovet al. [50] both experimentally and numerically using reducedorder model. They predicted (theoretically) that the pull-in voltage of the microbeam is 118.5 V while it was measured (experimentally) as 100 V. Das and Batra also determined the pull-in voltage of this beam using finite element method [51]. They reported that the pull-in voltage of the microbeam is between 99 V and 100 V. As seen in Table 3, good agreement between the present method and those of literature is achieved.

The literature confirms the substantial impact of Casimir force on the electromechanical performance of the NEMS/MEMS operate in submicron distances. Casimir force actuation of torsional MEMS has been conducted by previous researchers [28]. Casimir force can affect the rotational angle of torsional actuators with several micrometers gap distances [52]. By using a torsional oscillator Chan et al. reported significant Casimir force between a gold sphere and a silicon surface at distance of 150 500 nm [53]. Bressi et al. have reported that Casimir force can interfere the dynamic response of cantilever beam-type actuator with initial gaps less than 1μm [32]. E. Buks and M. L. Roukes have investigated the stiction, adhesion energy and the Casimir effect in micromechanical systems made of micromachined cantilever gold beams [54]. Using the doubly-clamped beam-type actuators, they have addressed the Metastability and the adhesion of micromechanical systems due to Casimir force [55]. More information about influence of quantum fluctuations on NEMS/MEMS devices and corresponding experimental findings can be found in Refs. [52, 56].
Unfortunately, all the experimental setups differ from that presented in this paper and cannot be used to compare with the proposed model. Most of the setups that were used for Casimir attraction measurements are based on rotational systems 27–29, [53]) and the beam-type systems [26,30–32] are not in the same condition with that of Fig. 1. However, to understand the contributions of the Casimir force to the adhesion of parallel conductive surfaces in a more visual way, the variation of electrostatic and Casimir attractions vs. the separation between the surfaces are plotted in Fig. 4. In this figure, the Casimir pressure (force per unite surface area) for infinite conductive parallel surfaces is compared to the electrostatic pressure between the surfaces for several values of the applied voltage V. If the gap distance, reduces gradually to 10 nm, the Casimir effect becomes increasingly closer to the electrostatic force at the voltage of 1 V. The magnitude of the Casimir force is larger than the electrostatic force at an electric potential of 0.5 V when the gap distance, h, is less than 30 nm. Note that these voltage values are within the operation range of new generation of NEMS with high sensitivity and low-actuation voltage [57–59].
The effect of Casimir force parameter λC on the pull-in instability of the system is demonstrated in Fig. 5 where the variation of fundamental frequency is plotted vs. the applied voltage. It is obvious from Fig. 5 that when the Casimir force parameter increases, the dynamic pull-in instability happens at lower values of actuation voltages. Moreover, before pull-in point, the greater λC causes the frequency of vibrations to decrease. The value of the non-dimensional natural frequency for some assigned values of nonlocal parameter, in the absence of Casimir effect and for λC = 10 is depicted in Fig. 6. One can observe that if the influence of dispersion force is ignored (i.e., for micro-scale gap) with raising nonlocal parameter ε0, the value of the natural frequency decreases, however, the value of dynamic pull-in voltage is increased. On the other hand, in the presence of Casimir attraction force (see Fig. 6b) and for λC = 10, by increasing the nonlocal parameter the fundamental frequency and dynamic pull-in voltage decrease.

394 H. M. Sedighi et al.: Modeling the effects of material properties on the pull-in instability
A NEMS switch/actuator/resonator might adhere to its substrate due to Casimir force (even without an applied voltage), if the minimum gap between the electrode and substrate is not considered. Besides interfering with the stability of freestanding nanostructures, the Casimir force can also induce undesired adhesion during the fabrication stages. The maximum permissible length of the nanowire Lmax, which is required to prevent stiction, is called the detachment length. For a given gap value, if the length of the nanowire exceeds Lmax, then the movable electrode sticks to the ground. Thus, the maximum length is very important in design and fabrication of the nanostructure. By substituting the critical value of λc into the definition of λc (Eq. (20)), the Lmax can be determined. As a case study, Fig. 7 shows the variation of Lmax as a function of initial gap and thickness for typical gold (Au) actuator. As seen, this finding reveals that Casimir force can substantially affect the stability of freestanding actuator in sub-micron scales.
Fig. 7 Variation of the detachment length, Lmax of freestanding actuator for various gap, thickness, and nonlocal parameter.
4.3 Effect of material characteristics and nonlocal parameter
The effects of nonlocal parameter ε0, gradient index n and actuation voltage V̄ , on the non-dimensional fundamental frequency of doubly-clamped FGM nano-actuators are listed in Table 4. The parameters used in this example are μmc = 2, ρmc = 0.5, f0 = 1, λC = 0.5, α = 1, γ = 0.3. As can be observed, for non-dimensional parameter μmc > 1, an increase in the nonlocal parameter, gradient index and applied voltage leads to lower natural frequencies of nano-bridges. Furthermore, according to the obtained results, it should be pointed out that for n = 2, ε0 = 0.3 dynamic pull-in instability occurs when the applied voltage approaches to Vpid = 6.97.
The influence of gradient index n on the pull-in behavior of vibrating FGM nano-bridge for μmc = 2 is depicted in Fig. 8. As can be seen, the fundamental frequency of the system decreases as the gradient index increases. Moreover, increasing the applied voltage leads to decrease in the fundamental frequency until the frequency vanishes and pull-in phenomenon occurs. In this situation, the frequency of oscillation drops to zero and the actuated nano-beam collapse onto the substrate. Figure 9 illustrates the fundamental frequency of nano-beam for some values of nondimensional parameter μmc. It is concluded that the fundamental frequency of nano-beam increases as the parameter μmc increases and pull-in instability happens at higher values of applied voltage.

Figure 10 shows the impact of material properties on the dynamic pull-in voltage of the considered nonlocal FGM nano-bridge using the different values of non-dimensional parameter μmc by varying the gradient index n. It appears from the illustrated results that if the non-dimensional parameter μmc is greater than one, the dynamic pull-in voltage decreases by increasing the gradient power index. However, if μmc < 1, as the gradient index increases, the dynamic pull-in voltage is also increased. On the other hand, if the power n approaches to infinity, the values of dynamic pull-in voltages tend toward to the pull-in voltage of isotropic material with μmc = 1.
In order to investigate the instability behavior of nano-structures under combined effects of nonlocal parameter and Casimir force, the dimensionless pull-in voltage has been plotted in Fig. 11. It is observed that by increasing the value of λC the dynamic pull-in voltage of the nano-actuator decreases until pull-in voltage disappears. Indeed, in these conditions, in the absence of any applied actuation, the free-standing nano-bridge becomes unstable if the Casimir force exceeds the critical quantity. It is clearly shown that if the Casimir parameter is smaller than the specific value (here λC 4.5), the larger values of ε0 would lead to larger values of pull-in voltage; while if the Casimir parameter becomes greater than this particular value, the dynamic pull-in voltage of the considered nonlocal nano-bridge decreases as the nonlocal parameter increases.

4.4 Stability analysis
The time history and phase portrait of FGM nano-actuator for different values of actuation parameter V̄ are depicted in Figs. 12a and 12b, respectively. It is clearly exhibited that at lower values of actuation voltage, the nano-actuator shows periodic motion around the stable center point. Before the pull-in point, as the applied actuation increases, time period of vibration tends to be increased. When the actuation parameter approaches to the critical pull-in voltage (here V̄pid = 7.6619), the motion trajectories in the phase plane approach to the unstable saddle node. There exists homoclinic orbit which starts from the unstable branch and goes back to the saddle node at the stable one. By increasing the applied voltage and above the pull-in voltage, the nano-beam becomes dynamically unstable and diverges to the rigid plate.

The trajectories of the FGM nano-bridge for different initial conditions and for four different system parameters are depicted in Fig. 13. According to the illustrated results in Fig. 13a, for the freestanding nano-bridge and in the absence of intermolecular force (for micro-scale gap), there exist periodic motions around the stable center point in the phase plane. As clearly shown in Fig. 13b, when the Casimir attraction is taken into consideration, even in the absence of applied voltage, the second fixed point which is an unstable saddle node appears in the phase plane while the stable and unstable branches of the fixed point, meet each other at a saddle-node bifurcation. In the presence of applied voltage (see Fig. 13c), two fixed point become closer to each other till the actuation voltage reaches the critical value namely the pull-in voltage. In other words, when the applied voltage reaches the dynamic pull-in voltage, as shown in Fig. 13d, the nano-bridge becomes unstable and collapse onto the substrate for any initial conditions.
5 Concluding remarks
In the current research, the dynamic pull-in behavior of FGM nano-bridges in the presence of Casimir force based on the nonlocal elasticity theory was investigated. Furthermore, the impact of material properties of functionally graded materials on the fundamental frequency and pull-in behavior was also studied. It was shown that when the μmcparameter is greater than one, by increasing the gradient index, the fundamental frequency decreases and pull-in instability occurs at lower values of applied voltage. On the other hand, if μmc < 1, as the gradient index increases, the dynamic pull-in voltage is also increased. Simulations in this paper revealed that in the absence of intermolecular force and applied actuation, the nano-structure undergoes periodic motion around the stable center point. When the dispersion force and/or actuation voltage included, the unstable saddle node appears in the phase plane and there exist homoclinic orbits in the phase portrait of nano-structure.

Study and researches about behavior of functionally graded materials (FGMs) have been an interesting topic during the past decades [1, 2].

In recent years, FGMs find increasing applications in micro- and nano- structures, such as thin films in the form of shape memory alloys [3, 4] and micro- or nano-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS) [5–7].
